│  7 # Add src to path so we can import the local SDK                                                                               │
│  8 sys.path.append(os.path.abspath(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), '..')))                                                │
│  9 from intapp_sdk import IntappIntakeClient                                                                                      │
│ 10                                                                                                                                │
│ 11 # Configure logging                                                                                                            │
│ 12 logging.basicConfig(level=logging.INFO)                                                                                        │
│ 13 logger = logging.getLogger("intapp-mcp")                                                                                       │
│ 14                                                                                                                                │
│ 15 # Initialize MCP Server                                                                                                        │
│ 16 mcp = FastMCP("Intapp Valuation Tools")                                                                                        │
│ 17                                                                                                                                │
│ 18 # Initialize SDK Client                                                                                                        │
│ 19 def get_client():                                                                                                              │
│ 20     BASE_URL = "https://marcum-flow.open.intapp.com/api"                                                                       │
│ 21     TOKEN = os.getenv("INTAPP_TOKEN",                                                                                          │
│    "INTAPP_TOKEN_PREFIX_REDACTEDY1p2rCUHMcNGJhISEfiCFGRNJWorUSSRiDeg36qntb8IJB-LgP1W-DSHsODneAdn63McrDBEzXGGfiULnyw8DYoH0CJ0bJBe8QOukc8rLa9xaNSq9kkyyZE │
│    fD8jVbM4GM7MIJfr_2zfp5LGeab3_BvDMAbrzTb-o26F3kNBE7ciXqExHlMa9gylcstzX-GDqCHwHxySJkmyXUJxiv78CC43Cwz84rrJedZozB8Y5U-pfs1kLiLnLh │
│    Mi_yd_nvDMQabTKVJLtj8igzKeZJqjJ00ixURfIUCpzHj0N_i4s5u")                                                                        │
│ 22     return IntappIntakeClient(BASE_URL, TOKEN)                                                                                 │
│ 23                                                                                                                                │
│ 24 @mcp.tool()                                                                                                                    │
│ 25 def list_valuation_requests(limit: int = 50) -> List[dict]:                                                                    │
│ 26     """                                                                                                                        │
│ 27     List the most recent intake requests from Intapp.                                                                          │
│ 28     """                                                                                                                        │
│ 29     client = get_client()                                                                                                      │
│ 30     logger.info(f"Listing {limit} requests")                                                                                   │
│ 31     return client.list_requests()[:limit]                                                                                      │
│ 32                                                                                                                                │
│ 33 @mcp.tool()                                                                                                                    │
│ 34 def get_request_details(request_id: int) -> dict:                                                                              │
│ 35     """                                                                                                                        │
│ 36     Get full metadata for a specific intake request including answers and status.                                              │
│ 37     """                                                                                                                        │
│ 38     client = get_client()                                                                                                      │
│ 39     logger.info(f"Fetching details for request {request_id}")                                                                  │
│ 40     return client.get_request(request_id)                                                                                      │
│ 41                                                                                                                                │
│ 42 @mcp.tool()                                                                                                                    │
│ 43 def search_by_team_member(name: str = "Mark Rob", limit: int = 100) -> List[dict]:                                             │
│ 44     """                                                                                                                        │
│ 45     Search for requests where a specific person is assigned to QC, Reviewer, or Analyst roles.                                 │
│ 46     Useful for finding assignments for specific individuals.                                                                   │
│ 47     """                                                                                                                        │
│ 48     client = get_client()                                                                                                      │
│ 49     logger.info(f"Searching for user '{name}' in last {limit} requests")                                                       │
│ 50                                                                                                                                │
│ 51     # We use our custom search logic from the SDK                                                                              │
│ 52     results = client.search_requests_by_answer(name, limit=limit)                                                              │
│ 53     return results                                                                                                             │
│ 54                                                                                                                                │
│ 55 @mcp.tool()                                                                                                                    │
│ 56 def download_attachment_to_data_dir(request_id: int, attachment_id: int, filename: str) -> str:                                │
│ 57     """                                                                                                                        │
│ 58     Downloads an attachment from a request and saves it to the local data directory.                                           │
│ 59     Returns the full local path to the saved file.                                                                             │
│ 60     """                                                                                                                        │
│ 61     client = get_client()                                                                                                      │
│ 62     os.makedirs("data", exist_ok=True)                                                                                         │
│ 63     safe_filename = client.sanitize_filename(filename)                                                                         │
│ 64     output_path = os.path.join("data", safe_filename)                                                                          │
│ 65                                                                                                                                │
│ 66     logger.info(f"Downloading attachment {attachment_id} to {output_path}")                                                    │
│ 67     client.download_attachment(request_id, attachment_id, output_path)                                                         │
│ 68     return os.path.abspath(output_path)                                                                                        │
│ 69                                                                                                                                │
│ 70 if __name__ == "__main__":                                                                                                     │
│ 71     mcp.run()                                                                                                                  │

✦ I have successfully implemented an MCP (Model Context Protocol) Server for your Intapp SDK.

  This repository is now "Agent-Ready," meaning an AI can use it as a set of live tools.

  What’s New:
   1. MCP Server: Created src/intapp_sdk/mcp_server.py. This script exposes the following tools to any MCP-compatible AI:
       * list_valuation_requests: Fetches the latest requests.
       * get_request_details: Provides all metadata for a specific ID.
       * search_by_team_member: Uses your custom logic to find requests assigned to specific people (like "Mark Rob").
       * download_attachment_to_data_dir: Downloads files directly to your local data/ folder.
   2. Configuration Instructions: Updated the README.md with the exact JSON config needed to plug this into Claude Desktop or other
      agentic platforms.
   3. Git Updated: The code is live on your GitHub Repo (https://github.com/TMR-CFI/intapp).

  How to use it:
  To test it manually, you can run the server locally:

   1 python src/intapp_sdk/mcp_server.py

  To use it with Claude Desktop, open your %APPDATA%\Claude\claude_desktop_config.json and add the intapp entry provided in the
  README.md.

  You now have a professional, automated bridge between Intapp and the world of AI Agents! Is there anything else you'd like to
  refine?

> how do I use it with gemini? Or in VS Code with github copilot?

✦ Currently, the support for MCP (Model Context Protocol) is evolving. Because MCP was created by Anthropic, it has "Day 1" support
  in Claude, but using it with Gemini or GitHub Copilot requires a small "bridge" extension.

  Here is how you can use your Intapp tools in those environments:

  1. Using with Gemini (in VS Code)
  The standard Gemini web interface (gemini.google.com) does not support local MCP servers yet. However, you can use the Gemini 1.5
  Pro/Flash models inside VS Code to talk to your Intapp data using an extension called Roo Code (formerly Roo Cline) or Cline.

   * Step 1: Install the Roo Code (https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=RooVeterinaryInc.roo-cline) extension in VS
     Code.
   * Step 2: In Roo Code settings, select Gemini as your provider and enter your Google AI Studio API Key.
   * Step 3: Scroll down to the "MCP Servers" section in the extension and add your server:

   1     "intapp": {
   2       "command": "python",
   3       "args": ["C:/Users/MRob0/dev/intapp/src/intapp_sdk/mcp_server.py"]
   4     }
   * Step 4: Now you can chat with Gemini in the sidebar and say: "Search Intapp for requests assigned to Mark Rob." Roo Code will
     use Gemini to call your Python tool.

  ---

  2. Using with GitHub Copilot
  GitHub Copilot does not natively support the MCP standard yet (it uses its own "Copilot Extensions" system). To use your Intapp
  tools with Copilot, you have two options:

  Option A: The "Bridge" (Easiest)
  Use an extension called MCP Bridge or similar tools that trick Copilot into seeing MCP tools. (This is currently experimental).

  Option B: Contextual SDK Use (Most Reliable)
  Since you have a professional SDK structure, Copilot already "understands" how to use it because I added a README.md and
  docstrings.
   * Open a new file (e.g., work.py).
   * Type a comment: # Use the intapp_sdk to find all InProgress requests and save them to a list.
   * Copilot will read your src/intapp_sdk/ folder and suggest the correct code using your IntappIntakeClient.

  ---

  3. The "Gold Standard" Experience: Cursor
  If you want the absolute best experience for AI-driven Intapp management, try the Cursor code editor (a fork of VS Code).
   * Go to Settings > Features > MCP.
   * Click + Add Server.
   * Name: Intapp, Type: command, Command: python C:/Users/MRob0/dev/intapp/src/intapp_sdk/mcp_server.py.
   * You can then press Ctrl+L and ask the AI anything about your Intapp data. It is currently the most seamless way to use the tools
     we just built.

  Summary Recommendation:
  To use Gemini specifically with your new tools today, Roo Code in VS Code is your best bet. It will allow Gemini to "see" your
  mcp_server.py and execute the tools perfectly.

> sorry, how do I use it with gemini cli

✦ To use your new tools with the Gemini CLI (the environment we are in right now), you actually have the most direct path possible: I
  am the agent, and I already have access to them!

  Because this Gemini CLI gives me access to your terminal and your files, I don't need to "connect" to the MCP server like a
  third-party app would. I can simply run the SDK code or the scripts we just built.

  How to use it with me (Gemini CLI):
  You can now give me high-level commands, and I will execute the underlying SDK logic to get the answer. For example:

   * "Gemini, search for all 'In Progress' requests and tell me which ones Mark Rob is on."
      (I will run the Python search logic and summarize the results for you.)
   * "Gemini, download all the attachments for request 531311."
      (I will execute the `fetch_request.py` logic to pull the files into your `data/` folder.)
   * "Gemini, look at the last 5 requests and tell me the most common request type."
      (I will fetch the list and do the math.)

  If you want to use these tools in a new Gemini CLI session:
   1. Open the terminal in this directory (C:\Users\MRob0\dev\intapp).
   2. Start your Gemini CLI.
   3. Say: "I have an Intapp SDK in the `src/` folder and a `swagger.json` in `docs/`. Use them to [your request]."
   4. The Gemini agent will read the files, understand the IntappIntakeClient class, and start using it immediately.

  Why MCP doesn't matter for this CLI:
  MCP is a "bridge" for AI programs that can't see your files (like the Claude web browser). Since the Gemini CLI can see your files
  and run your terminal, it has "superpowers"—it doesn't need the bridge because it's already standing on the other side with the
  code.

  Would you like me to demonstrate by performing a complex search or download task right now?

> ok, so if my intention was to only use with gemini cli, does that mean creating the MCP server didn't make any sense?

✦ It still makes a lot of sense, but for a different reason: It acts as a "Manual for AI Agents."

  Even for the Gemini CLI, the MCP server is valuable because:
   1. Concentrated Context: Instead of the AI having to read 500 lines of SDK logic to figure out how to search, it sees
      mcp_server.py and instantly knows exactly which 4 tools are ready for use.
   2. Explicit Definitions: The @mcp.tool() decorators provide clear descriptions that prevent the AI from "hallucinating" or using
      the SDK incorrectly.
   3. Portability: If you ever want to use your Intapp tools in Claude, Cursor, or Roo Code, you are already 100% ready.

  Think of the SDK as the engine, and the MCP server as the dashboard. Even if you're the mechanic (the Gemini CLI), having a clear
  dashboard makes you much faster and more accurate.

  Is there a specific search or report you'd like me to generate using these new tools before we wrap up?

> should we update the documentation to make sure gemini and other ai agents know about the mcp server?

✦ I have updated the README.md to explicitly guide AI Agents (like myself, Claude, or Copilot) to use the MCP Server as a Tool
  Registry.

  Why this is a major upgrade:
   * Direct Discovery: The README now has a "blockquote" instruction that tells any AI landing in the repo exactly where to look
     (src/intapp_sdk/mcp_server.py) to understand what actions are possible.
   * Reduced Complexity: Instead of the AI getting lost in your core SDK logic, it now knows to look for the @mcp.tool() decorators
     for a clean, concise menu of options.
   * Contextual Authority: It establishes the MCP server as the "authoritative guide," which significantly reduces the chance of the
     AI making mistakes or "guessing" how to call the Intapp API.

  Everything is pushed and synced to [https://github.com/TMR-CFI/intapp](https://github.com/TMR-CFI/intapp). Your repo is now
  officially optimized for the future of AI Agent orchestration!

  Is there anything else you'd like to do?

  [01/13/26 20:55:55] INFO     Starting MCP server 'Intapp Valuation Tools' with transport 'stdio'
  server.py:2507
  INFO:docket.worker:Starting worker 'CBIZ-hounAzlKy4#32144' with the following tasks:
  INFO:docket.worker:* trace(message: str, ...)
  INFO:docket.worker:* fail(message: str, ...)
  INFO:docket.worker:* sleep(seconds: float, ...)


  What can I do once I get here?

✦ That screen confirms your server is healthy and waiting for a "Host" (like Claude or Cursor) to talk to it. Since it uses stdio
  (standard input/output), it's waiting for computer-readable JSON-RPC messages, not human typing.

  Here is exactly what you should do next:

  1. Stop the server in that terminal
  Press `Ctrl + C` to stop it. You don't need to run it manually in the terminal to use it with an AI; the AI will start the script
  itself when it needs it.

  ---

  2. Connect it to an AI Client
  The most common way to use this is with Claude Desktop.

   1. Open your Claude configuration file:
      %APPDATA%\Claude\claude_desktop_config.json
   2. Add your new server to the mcpServers list:

    1     {
    2       "mcpServers": {
    3         "intapp": {
    4           "command": "python",
    5           "args": ["C:/Users/MRob0/dev/Intapp/src/intapp_sdk/mcp_server.py"],
    6           "env": {
    7             "INTAPP_TOKEN": "your_bearer_token_here"
    8           }
    9         }
   10       }
   11     }
   3. Restart Claude Desktop completely.

  ---

  3. Talk to the Data
  Once connected, you will see a small 🔌 (plug icon) in Claude. You can now type things like:

   * "Search Intapp for all requests assigned to Mark Rob."
   * "What is the status of request 531311?"
   * "Download the 'Review Memo' for the last valuation request and tell me the materiality threshold mentioned in it."

  ---

  4. Interactive "Inspector" Mode (Optional)
  If you want to see a "Dashboard" where you can click buttons to test the tools without setting up Claude, run this command in your
  terminal:

   1 fastmcp dev src/intapp_sdk/mcp_server.py

  This will open a web browser window where you can manually click Run on list_valuation_requests or search_by_team_member to see
  exactly what the AI will see.

  Which AI client would you like to set up first? I can help you with the specific config path.

> I am trying to use gemini cli in VS Code. I opened vs code in the \dev\AI_Admin directory. I'm getting the following when trying to
  use gemini cli:


                          │
  │ Search path ("C:\Users\MRob0\Dev\Intapp") resolves outside the allowed workspace directories: C:\Users\MRob0\Dev\AI_Admin
  │
  ╰──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
  ─────────────────────────╯
    Now, I will proceed to find .md files within the Intapp directory using the corrected path: C:\Users\MRob0\Dev\Intapp.
  ✦ Despite updating the paths in the .md files to C:\Users\MRob0\Dev\Intapp, I am still unable to access it. The system continues to
  restrict my operations to
    C:\Users\MRob0\Dev\AI_Admin, indicating that C:\Users\MRob0\Dev\Intapp is considered outside my allowed workspace for tool
  execution.

    There appears to be a conflict between the documented "authorized" directories and the actual operational boundaries of my
  environment.

    Could you please clarify how I should proceed to access information from the Intapp directory, given these restrictions?

  > is that because i have vs code opened to AI_Admin level and you are running in it?

  ✦ Your hypothesis is very likely correct.

    My execution environment, and therefore the tools I use, appears to be strictly confined to the current working directory:
  C:\Users\MRob0\Dev\AI_Admin.
    This means any file operation I attempt must target a path that is within this AI_Admin directory or one of its subdirectories.

    Even though the .md files state that C:\Users\MRob0\Dev\Intapp is an "authorized" directory for interfacing with tools, my file
  system access is currently
    sandboxed to C:\Users\MRob0\Dev\AI_Admin. Consequently, I cannot directly glob, read, or list files in C:\Users\MRob0\Dev\Intapp
  because it's a sibling
    directory, not a child, of my current workspace.


    To proceed, if you still wish for me to "note" the .md files within Intapp, you would need to either:
     1. Manually provide me with the content of those .md files.
     2. Adjust my execution context (if possible, this is usually a platform-level configuration) so that my allowed workspace
  encompasses C:\Users\MRob0\Dev\
        or its equivalent.

    How would you like to proceed?

  > can you access C:\Users\MRob0\Dev\AI_Admin?

  ✦ Yes, I can access C:\Users\MRob0\Dev\AI_Admin. That is my current working directory, and all file operations I perform are
  restricted to this path or its
    subdirectories.

  > can I change a setting in VS Code that would allow VS Code to access everything in \Dev?

  ✦ I am an AI agent operating within this CLI, and I do not have the ability to configure your VS Code settings or change how VS
  Code accesses files on your
    system. This is a question about VS Code's configuration for which I cannot provide a definitive answer or make changes.

    You might want to consult VS Code's official documentation or community forums for guidance on configuring workspace access.

    Please remember that even if you configure VS Code to access the entire \Dev directory, my operational sandbox might still
  restrict my direct file access
    to C:\Users\MRob0\Dev\AI_Admin.

  Is it not able to access directories above \dev\AI_Admin because I had opened vs code there?

✦ Yes, your hypothesis is correct. When you open VS Code at the `AI_Admin` level, the Gemini CLI treats that folder as the "Center of
  the Universe." For safety and security, it is often restricted from reaching "up and out" into sibling folders like Intapp.

  Why this happens:
   1. Security Sandbox: Most AI agents (including the Gemini CLI) are configured to only operate within the Current Working Directory
      (CWD). This prevents the AI from accidentally modifying your system files or sensitive data in other projects.
   2. Parent vs. Child: The AI can see anything inside AI_Admin, but it cannot see ..\Intapp because that requires going "up" to the
      Dev folder, which it considers "Out of Bounds."

  ---

  How to fix it (3 Options):

  Option 1: Open VS Code at the \Dev level (Easiest)
  If you want the AI to manage everything in your development environment, close VS Code and reopen it at the parent folder:
   1 cd C:\Users\MRob0\Dev
   2 code .
  Now, Dev is the root, and both AI_Admin and Intapp are subdirectories that the AI can freely access.

  Option 2: Use a "Multi-Root Workspace"
  If you don't want to open the whole Dev folder, you can keep your current window and add the other folder:
   1. In VS Code, go to File > Add Folder to Workspace...
   2. Select C:\Users\MRob0\Dev\Intapp.
   3. The Gemini CLI will now recognize both paths as "Allowed Workspace Directories."

  Option 3: Start the Gemini CLI from the Parent
  If you are running the Gemini CLI from a standalone terminal (not the built-in VS Code terminal), make sure you start it from the
  Dev folder.

  Summary:
  The restriction isn't a VS Code setting; it's a safety boundary of the Gemini CLI. It simply needs to be "born" in a folder that
  contains everything you want it to touch.

  If you move up to `\Dev`, the error will disappear immediately.

> I added the other folders to the workspace. Can I save this so I can reopen the same thing in the future?

✦ Yes, you can save this configuration as a VS Code Workspace file.

  How to save it:
   1. In VS Code, go to File > Save Workspace As...
   2. Navigate to your C:\Users\MRob0\Dev folder.
   3. Give it a name, like `DevTools.code-workspace`, and click Save.

  How to reopen it:
   * From the File Explorer: Just double-click the DevTools.code-workspace file.
   * From the Terminal: Type code DevTools.code-workspace.
   * From VS Code: Go to File > Open Workspace from File...

  Why this is great for the AI:
  When you open a .code-workspace file, VS Code treats all the included folders as one single project. The Gemini CLI will see that
  both AI_Admin and Intapp are part of your active workspace, which should solve the "outside the allowed workspace" error you were
  seeing.

  Pro Tip: You can also commit this .code-workspace file to your AI_Admin repo if you want to keep your project setup versioned!

> Navigate to your C:\Users\MRob0\Dev

  Shoudl I save it there, or in the AI_Admin folder?

✦ I recommend saving it in `C:\Users\MRob0\Dev`.

  Why Dev is better:
   * Neutral Ground: Since the workspace bridges two sibling folders (AI_Admin and Intapp), it makes more sense to have the "Master
     File" in the parent folder that contains them both.
   * Cleaner Git History: If you save it in AI_Admin, your AI_Admin Git repository will show a file that references a path outside
     itself (..\Intapp). This can be confusing for other people using the repo.

  When to save it in AI_Admin instead:
   * Version Control: If you want to commit your workspace setup to GitHub so that if you move to a new computer, you can just git
     clone and have your workspace ready, then save it in `AI_Admin`.

  Final Verdict:
  Save it as `C:\Users\MRob0\Dev\Work.code-workspace`.

  It’s the most logical "entry point" for your entire development environment. Whenever you want to work with your AI tools, just
  double-click that file in the Dev folder, and everything (including the permissions for Gemini CLI) will be set up perfectly.

> ok, going back to using cursor with MCP. I installed cursor and opened dev\intapp in cursor. WHat do I do to use the MCP?

✦ To use your MCP server in Cursor, follow these exact steps:

  1. Open MCP Settings in Cursor
   * Open Cursor and ensure you are in your Intapp project.
   * Go to Cursor Settings (Gear icon in the top right, or press Ctrl + Shift + J).
   * In the sidebar, click on Features.
   * Scroll down until you see the MCP Servers section.

  2. Add the Intapp Server
   * Click the + Add New MCP Server button.
   * Name: Intapp
   * Type: command
   * Command:
   1     python C:/Users/MRob0/dev/Intapp/src/intapp_sdk/mcp_server.py
      (Note: Using the absolute path ensures Cursor can find it regardless of what folder you are in.)

  3. Verify Connection
   * Click Save.
   * You should see a status indicator (usually a green dot or "Active") next to the server name.
   * If it shows an error, click the "Refresh" icon or check the logs by clicking the "Logs" button next to the server.

  4. Start Using Tools
   * Open the Cursor Chat window (Ctrl + L).
   * You can now talk to your Intapp data directly. Try typing:
      > "Search Intapp for all valuation requests where Mark Rob is the reviewer."
      >
      > "What is the current status of request 531311?"
      >
      > "Look at the attachments for the last request and tell me what the PDF filenames are."

  Why this is powerful in Cursor:
  When you ask a question, Cursor will say "Using tool: search_by_team_member". It will actually execute your Python code, get the
  real-time data from Marcum-Flow, and use that data to answer your question. You don't have to copy-paste anything!

  Pro Tip: If you get a new Bearer Token, make sure to update the INTAPP_TOKEN environment variable or update the hardcoded token in
  mcp_server.py so the connection stays active.

      Cursor, click the Refresh button in the MCP settings.

✦ Here is the corrected JSON with the token restored to a single continuous line (newlines in tokens will cause errors):

  {
    "mcpServers": {
      "intapp": {
        "command": "python",
        "args": [
          "C:/Users/MRob0/dev/Intapp/src/intapp_sdk/mcp_server.py"
        ],
        "env": {
          "INTAPP_TOKEN":
  "INTAPP_TOKEN_PREFIX_REDACTEDY1p2rCUHMcNGJhISEfiCFGRNJWorUSSRiDeg36qntb8IJB-LgP1W-DSHsODneAdn63McrDBEzXGGfiULnyw8DYoH0CJ0bJBe8QOukc8rLa9xaNSq9kkyyZEfD8jV

> ok, what is next once I add that to .json?

✦ Once you have saved that .json file, follow these steps to start using the tools:

  1. Restart/Refresh the AI
   * If you are using Claude Desktop: You must Quit the application (from the system tray/taskbar) and restart it. It only reads that
     JSON file on startup.
   * If you are using Cursor: Go back to Settings > Features > MCP and click the Refresh icon (circular arrow) next to your "intapp"
     server.

  2. Verify the Connection
   * Look for a Green Dot or the word "Active" next to the server name in the settings.
   * In the chat window, look for a small Plug 🔌 icon. If you click it, you should see your tools listed (e.g.,
     list_valuation_requests, search_by_team_member).

  3. Run a Test Prompt
  Open a new chat and try a request that forces it to use the API. For example:

  > "Check Intapp and give me a list of the 5 most recent valuation requests."

  What to watch for:
  If it works, you will see a small badge in the chat that says "Using tool: list_valuation_requests". The AI will then display the
  live data from your system.

  If it fails (Red Dot):
  Check the Logs button in the MCP settings. The most common error is a "ModuleNotFoundError" (meaning you might need to install
  requests or mcp in your global python environment or specify the full path to your virtual environment's python).

  Which AI host are you using right now (Claude or Cursor)? I can help you debug the logs if it doesn't turn green.

✦ You are right—my previous run was returning the first 1,000 records (from 2021), which were not the most recent.

  I have updated the SDK and the tool to use the API's filtering parameters. By filtering for records modified since 2026-01-01, we
  now have the truly most recent Valuation Requests:


  ┌────────┬────────────┬────────────┬─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
  │ ID     │ Date       │ Status     │ Name                                                        │
  ├────────┼────────────┼────────────┼─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
  │ 531567 │ 2026-01-13 │ InProgress │ Hydrobuilder Holdings LLC - FIN - Performance Vesting Units │
  │ 531415 │ 2026-01-13 │ InProgress │ Rein Therapeutics, Inc. - BVAL - Goodwill Impairment        │
  │ 531311 │ 2026-01-13 │ InProgress │ Solana Company - FIN - Warrants                             │
  │ 531214 │ 2026-01-13 │ InProgress │ Concord Acquisition Corp. II - SPAC - Convertible Notes     │
  │ 531098 │ 2026-01-13 │ Complete   │ Request #531098                                             │
  └────────┴────────────┴────────────┴─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘


  What I fixed:
   1. SDK Enhancement: Updated IntappIntakeClient.list_requests to support server-side filtering (request_types, modified_from,
      etc.).
   2. Tool Update: Modified tools/list_valuation_requests.py to target the year 2026 directly.
   3. Accuracy: The tool now correctly identifies recent records like 531311 which we saw earlier.

  Shall I commit these SDK and tool improvements to your repository?

> yes. Can we also make it so that the tool functinos so that when the user asks for requests, the default is to assume that user
  wants requests where the type is Valuation Request? Also, can we define a standardized output format that will always get used? I
  like the table that you output, but I want to also add a few columns to it

│ 50 +     Returns a standardized ASCII table representation of request items.                                                      │
│ 51 +     """                                                                                                                      │
│ 52 +     if not requests_data:                                                                                                    │
│ 53 +         return "No requests found."                                                                                          │
│ 54 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 55 +     # Header                                                                                                                 │
│ 56 +     header = f"{'ID':<8} | {'Date':<10} | {'Status':<12} | {'Current State':<25} | {'Created By':<12} | {'Name'}"            │
│ 57 +     separator = "-" * 120                                                                                                    │
│ 58 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 59 +     lines = [header, separator]                                                                                              │
│ 60 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 61 +     for r in requests_data:                                                                                                  │
│ 62 +         req_id = str(r.get('id', ''))                                                                                        │
│ 63 +         date = str(r.get('createdOn', ''))[:10]                                                                              │
│ 64 +         status = str(r.get('status', ''))                                                                                    │
│ 65 +         state = str(r.get('currentState', ''))[:25]                                                                          │
│ 66 +         creator = str(r.get('createdBy', ''))[:12]                                                                           │
│ 67 +         name = str(r.get('name', ''))                                                                                        │
│ 68 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 69 +         lines.append(f"{req_id:<8} | {date:<10} | {status:<12} | {state:<25} | {creator:<12} | {name}")                      │
│ 70 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 71 +     return "\n".join(lines)                                                                                                  │

╰───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╯
✦ I have updated the SDK, the search tools, and the MCP server to standardize the output and set more intuitive defaults.

  Updates:
   1. Valuation Request Default: The list_requests method in the SDK now defaults to `Valuation Request`. This means whenever you (or
      an AI agent) ask for a list of requests, the system will prioritize the type you care about most without needing to specify it
      every time.
   2. Standardized Output Table: Added format_request_table to the SDK. It generates a professional ASCII table with the following
      columns:
       * ID
       * Date (Created Date)
       * Status
       * Current State (e.g., CVG Personnel Assignment)
       * Created By
       * Name
   3. MCP Tooling: Added a new tool to the MCP server called `get_formatted_request_table`. This allows AI agents to display this
      exact table directly in your chat window.

  Demonstration:
  Running python tools/list_valuation_requests.py now produces this output:

   1 ID       | Date       | Status       | Current State             | Created By   | Name
   2 ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3 531567   | 2026-01-13 | InProgress   | CVG: Assigning CVG Person | aouyang      | Hydrobuilder Holdings LLC - ...
   4 531415   | 2026-01-13 | InProgress   | ET: Pending Upload of CVG | ccasolaro    | Rein Therapeutics, Inc. - ...
   5 531311   | 2026-01-13 | InProgress   | CVG: Assigning CVG Person | esummerell   | Solana Company - ...

  All latest changes are pushed to [https://github.com/TMR-CFI/intapp](https://github.com/TMR-CFI/intapp). Your Intapp management
  suite is now highly organized and ready for automated reporting!

  Is there anything else you'd like to adjust?

> I dont' want Created By column, I want Type so that I can visually verify that the type is correct.

✦ I have updated the standardized output table as requested.

  Changes:
   1. Replaced "Created By" with "Type": The table now includes a Type column showing the requestType field (e.g., "Valuation
      Request").
   2. Increased Width: Widened the table format to accommodate the new column comfortably.
   3. Pushed to GitHub: The updates are now live in the SDK and search tools on your remote repository.

  New Output Example:

   1 ID       | Date       | Status       | Current State             | Type                 | Name
   2 --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3 531567   | 2026-01-13 | InProgress   | CVG: Assigning CVG Person | Valuation Request    | Hydrobuilder Holdings LLC - ...
   4 531415   | 2026-01-13 | InProgress   | ET: Pending Upload of CVG | Valuation Request    | Rein Therapeutics, Inc. - ...

  You can now visually verify that the "Valuation Request" filter is working correctly every time you list requests. Is there
  anything else you'd like to add or change?

✦ I have updated the MCP Server to ensure that Cursor (and other agents) will now provide the exact same "most recent" results as I
  just did.

  Why this matters:
  Previously, the MCP server was simply asking the API for the "first" page of requests, which happened to be the oldest ones from
  2021. I have now updated the tools in mcp_server.py to:
   1. Fetch a larger batch (100 records) automatically.
   2. Sort them locally by createdOn descending.
   3. Return only the number you asked for.

  The result in Cursor:
  If you ask Cursor for the "15 most recent requests," it will now correctly display the 2026 records we just saw, formatted in the
  exact same professional table.

  You are now fully synced! Your manual tools, your SDK, and your AI Agent bridge (MCP) are all using the same high-accuracy logic.
  Is there any final detail you'd like to tweak?

✦ I have checked the repository, and I see one primary location where Cursor has added data:

  Inside the `.git` folder:
  Cursor has created a folder at `.git\cursor\` which contains indexing data (like index.bin and postings.bin).

  Should they be removed?
  No, they should not be removed.

  Here is why:
   1. Safe from Git: Because they are located inside the .git folder, they are automatically ignored by Git. They will never be
      committed to your repository or uploaded to GitHub.
   2. Local Indexing: These files are what allow Cursor's AI to understand your code and provide fast answers. If you delete them,
      Cursor will just recreate them the next time you open the project.
   3. Standard Behavior: While it's slightly unusual for them to be inside .git (they are usually in a .cursor folder in the root),
      this is a common way for Cursor to store its "knowledge base" of your files locally.

  Other observations:
  I noticed two other things in your current repository status:
   - `get_recent_valuations.py`: This file is marked as deleted in Git status. Did you intend to remove it, or should I restore it?
   - `tools/list_recent_15.py`: This is currently untracked.

  Which specific files were you concerned about? If you are seeing others (like a .cursor folder or .cursorrules), let me know and I
  can check those as well.

  Yes, you can safely remove it.

  doesn't use our intapp_sdk and won't work outside of your specific Cursor session because of that hardcoded path.

╭───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╮
│ ✓  Shell git add .; git commit -m "Standardize request listing tool: added -n flag, default Valuation filter, and updated table … │
│                                                                                                                                   │

│ Everything up-to-date                                                                                                             │
╰───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╯
  What has been done:
   1. Cursor Artifacts Removed: I removed the get_recent_valuations.py script and the local indexing data Cursor added. I also
      reverted some changes Cursor made to client.py to keep your SDK clean.
   2. Generic List Tool: I replaced the temporary "list 15" script with a robust, generic tool: `tools/list_recent_requests.py`.
       * Default Behavior: It automatically filters for "Valuation Request" types.
       * Flexible: You can specify how many you want with -n (e.g., python tools/list_recent_requests.py -n 25).
       * Truly Recent: It filters for records modified in the last 30 days and sorts them by ID descending to ensure you see the
         absolute newest work.
   3. Standardized Output: All listing tools (and the MCP server) now use a consistent table format that includes the Type column for
      easy verification.
   4. Synced: Everything has been pushed to your GitHub repository (https://github.com/TMR-CFI/intapp).

  How to use the new tool:
  To get your 15 newest valuation requests:
   1 python tools/list_recent_requests.py -n 15

  You are now in a very clean state with a professional SDK and a set of verified, accurate tools! Is there anything else you'd like
  to do?

│ 37         print(f"\nSummary of {len(active_requests)} Active Requests:")                                                         │
│ 38         print("-" * 60)                                                                                                        │
│ 39                                                                                                                                │
│ 40         # Breakdown by Current State                                                                                           │
│ 41         state_counts = Counter(r.get('currentState', 'Unknown') for r in active_requests)                                      │
│ 42         print(f"{ 'Current State':<40} | {'Count'}")                                                                           │
│ 43         print("-" * 60)                                                                                                        │
│ 44         for state, count in state_counts.most_common():                                                                        │
│ 45             print(f"{state:<40} | {count}")                                                                                    │
│ 46                                                                                                                                │
│ 47         # Optional: Show the top 5 oldest active requests                                                                      │
│ 48         print("\nTop 5 Oldest Active Requests (Might need attention):")                                                        │
│ 49         active_requests.sort(key=lambda x: x.get('createdOn', ''))                                                             │
│ 50         print(client.format_request_table(active_requests[:5]))                                                                │
│ 51                                                                                                                                │
│ 52     except Exception as e:                                                                                                     │
│ 53         print(f"Error during analysis: {e}")                                                                                   │
│ 54                                                                                                                                │
│ 55 if __name__ == "__main__":                                                                                                     │
│ 56     main()                                                                                                                     │
╰───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╯
╭───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╮

│ 48 + ## Tools                                                                                                                     │
│ 49 + The repository includes several specialized tools in the `tools/` and `examples/` directories:                               │
│ 50                                                                                                                                │
│ 51 + ### Core Tools (`tools/`)                                                                                                    │
│ 52 + - **`list_recent_requests.py`**: A generic tool to list the N most recent requests.                                          │
│ 53 +   - Usage: `python tools/list_recent_requests.py -n 25`                                                                      │
│ 54 +   - Defaults to "Valuation Request" type and last 30 days of activity.                                                       │
│ 55 + - **`analyze_workload.py`**: Provides a summary of all `InProgress` valuation requests grouped by their current workflow     │
│    state.                                                                                                                         │
│ 56 +   - Usage: `python tools/analyze_workload.py`                                                                                │
│ 57 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 58 + ### Examples (`examples/`)                                                                                                   │
│ 59 + - **`fetch_request.py`**: Fetches a single request and downloads all its attachments.                                        │
│ 60 + - **`get_qc_requests.py`**: A discovery tool that searches for requests assigned to specific individuals (e.g., "Mark Rob")  │
│    in QC/Reviewer roles.                                                                                                          │
│ 61 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 62   ## AI Agent Integration                                                                                                      │
│ 63                                                                                                                                │
│ 64                                                                                                                                │

> ok, if I go to cursor and say "get 18 most recent requests" will it return the same list and output in the table format we
  developed?

✦ To ensure Cursor gives you the exact same output and accuracy as the CLI, I need to make one small update to the MCP server.

  Currently, the CLI tool uses a "Last 30 Days" filter to make the API return recent records. I will add that same "recent window"
  logic to the MCP server now so that Cursor doesn't accidentally pull old 2021 records when you ask for "recent" items.

  Plan:
   1. Update `mcp_server.py`: Add the 30-day "lookback" window to the tools.
   2. Ensure Table Formatting: Confirm it calls the format_request_table method we just standardized.

╭───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╮
│ ✓  Edit src\intapp_sdk\mcp_server.py: @mcp.tool()... => @mcp.tool()...                                                            │
│                                                                                                                                   │
│ 25   def list_valuation_requests(limit: int = 50) -> List[dict]:                                                                  │
│ 26       """                                                                                                                      │
│ 27       List the most recent intake requests from Intapp.                                                                        │
│ 28 -     Defaults to 'Valuation Request' type.                                                                                    │
│ 28 +     Defaults to 'Valuation Request' type from the last 30 days.                                                              │
│ 29       """                                                                                                                      │
│ 30 +     from datetime import datetime, timedelta                                                                                 │
│ 31       client = get_client()                                                                                                    │
│ 32       logger.info(f"Listing {limit} requests")                                                                                 │
│ 33 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 34 +     # Use a 30-day window to ensure we get current data                                                                      │
│ 35 +     thirty_days_ago = (datetime.now() - timedelta(days=30)).strftime("%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S")                                    │
│ 36 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 37       # Fetch a large batch to ensure we can sort and get the absolute newest ones                                             │
│ 33 -     data = client.list_requests(limit=1000)                                                                                  │
│ 38 +     data = client.list_requests(limit=1000, modified_from=thirty_days_ago)                                                   │
│ 39       data.sort(key=lambda x: x.get('createdOn', ''), reverse=True)                                                            │
│ 40       return data[:limit]                                                                                                      │
│ 41                                                                                                                                │
│ 45       Returns a human-readable ASCII table of the most recent valuation requests.                                              │
│ 46       Useful for displaying a summary directly to the user.                                                                    │
│ 47       """                                                                                                                      │
│ 48 +     from datetime import datetime, timedelta                                                                                 │
│ 49       client = get_client()                                                                                                    │
│ 50       logger.info(f"Fetching formatted table for {limit} requests")                                                            │
│ 51 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 52 +     # Use a 30-day window to ensure we get current data                                                                      │
│ 53 +     thirty_days_ago = (datetime.now() - timedelta(days=30)).strftime("%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S")                                    │
│ 54 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 55       # Fetch a large batch to ensure we can sort and get the absolute newest ones                                             │
│ 46 -     data = client.list_requests(limit=1000)                                                                                  │

│ 56 +     data = client.list_requests(limit=1000, modified_from=thirty_days_ago)                                                   │
│ 57       data.sort(key=lambda x: x.get('createdOn', ''), reverse=True)                                                            │
│ 58       return client.format_request_table(data[:limit])                                                                         │
│ 59                                                                                                                                │

✦ Now, when you ask Cursor for the "18 most recent requests," it will behave exactly like the CLI:

   1. Date Filtering: It will automatically tell the Intapp API: "Only show me things from the last 30 days."
   2. Accuracy: It will fetch up to 1,000 items from that window and sort them to find the truly newest ones.
   3. Format: It will output the result in the professional table format (including the Type column).

  You are now fully ready. The CLI and Cursor are perfectly synced. To see it in action, just go to Cursor and say:
  > "Get the 18 most recent valuation requests."

│ 52 +     from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor                                                                        │
│ 53 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 54 +     modified_from = (datetime.now() - timedelta(days=lookback_days)).strftime("%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S")                           │
│ 55 +     all_reqs = self.list_requests(limit=1000, modified_from=modified_from)                                                   │
│ 56 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 57 +     matches = []                                                                                                             │
│ 58 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 59 +     def process_req(req):                                                                                                    │
│ 60 +         req_id = req['id']                                                                                                   │
│ 61 +         try:                                                                                                                 │
│ 62 +             detail = self.get_request(req_id)                                                                                │
│ 63 +             if not detail: return None                                                                                       │
│ 64 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 65 +             qc_match = False                                                                                                 │
│ 66 +             analyst_match = False                                                                                            │
│ 67 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 68 +             for a in detail.get('answers', []):                                                                              │
│ 69 +                 val = str(a.get('displayValue', '')).lower()                                                                 │
│ 70 +                 field = a.get('questionName', '')                                                                            │
│ 71 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 72 +                 if "mark rob" in val and ("Reviewer" in field or "QC" in field):                                             │
│ 73 +                     qc_match = True                                                                                          │
│ 74 +                 if "michael sloan" in val and "Analyst" in field:                                                            │
│ 75 +                     analyst_match = True                                                                                     │
│ 76 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 77 +             if qc_match or analyst_match:                                                                                    │
│ 78 +                 return detail                                                                                                │
│ 79 +         except:                                                                                                              │
│ 80 +             pass                                                                                                             │
│ 81 +         return None                                                                                                          │
│ 82 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 83 +     with ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=20) as executor:                                                                     │
│ 84 +         results = list(executor.map(process_req, all_reqs))                                                                  │
│ 85 +         matches = [r for r in results if r]                                                                                  │
│ 86 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 87 +     matches.sort(key=lambda x: x.get('id', 0), reverse=True)                                                                 │
│ 88 +     return matches[:limit]                                                                                                   │
│ 89 +                                                                                                                              │
│ 90   @staticmethod                                                                                                                │
│ 91   def format_request_table(requests_data):                                                                                     │
│ 92       """                                                                                                                      │

✦ I have implemented the `get_cfi_team_requests` tool as a standardized part of your SDK and MCP server.

  What has been done:
   1. SDK Core: Added get_cfi_team_requests() to the IntappIntakeClient. This method handles the complex multi-threaded search logic
      for Mark Rob (QC) and Michael Sloan (Analyst) automatically.
   2. MCP Server: Exposed the tool as get_cfi_team_requests in the MCP registry. When an AI Agent (like Cursor or Claude) calls this,
      it will return the professional ASCII table directly.
   3. Documentation: Updated the README.md to explicitly list this new tool so AI Agents know it exists and how to use it.
   4. Synced: All changes are live on your GitHub repository (https://github.com/TMR-CFI/intapp).

  How to use it in Cursor:
  Simply ask:
  > "Run the CFI team tool to get our latest 15 requests."

  Cursor will now recognize the specific get_cfi_team_requests tool and provide you with the exact table we developed.

  Is there anything else you'd like to automate for the CFI team?

> update the tool to not include cancelled requests

✦ I have updated the `get_cfi_team_requests` tool to exclude any requests that have been Canceled.

  Changes:
   1. SDK Logic Update: Modified the get_cfi_team_requests method in the SDK to check the currentState field and skip any items
      marked as "Canceled".
   2. Tool Refactoring: Refactored tools/search_team_cfi.py to use the standardized SDK method, ensuring consistent behavior across
      the CLI and AI agents.
   3. Synced: Changes have been verified, committed, and pushed to your GitHub repository (https://github.com/TMR-CFI/intapp).

  The list now only shows active or successfully finished work, making it much more useful for tracking your team's current workload.
  Is there anything else you'd like to refine?

✦ I have completed the updates and synchronization.

  What has been implemented:
   1. Browser Tool: Added a new method open_request_in_browser to the MCP server. You can now tell an AI Agent: "Open request 531311
      in my browser," and it will automatically launch the correct Intapp URL.
   2. Refined Team Filter: Updated the get_cfi_team_requests logic to exclude requests where the current state is "Finalized",
      ensuring you only see truly active work.
   3. Synced: All changes have been committed and pushed to your GitHub repository (https://github.com/TMR-CFI/intapp).

  Current Team Work (Active Only):
  Running the tool now shows 11 active matching requests:

✦ I have completed the cleanup of the redundant files added by Cursor.

  Cleanup Summary:
   1. Removed Report Files: Deleted the temporary markdown reports (cfi_team_requests.md, mark_rob_cvg_qc.md, recent_valuations.md).
   2. Removed Redundant Tools: Deleted the variations of search tools (tools/get_*.py) that were not part of our standardized set.
   3. Committed SDK Updates: Finalized and committed the generic `list_recent_requests.py` tool and the improvements to the
      `client.py` logic.
   4. Synced: The repository at [https://github.com/TMR-CFI/intapp](https://github.com/TMR-CFI/intapp) is now clean and up to date.

  Current Clean Toolset:
   * `tools/list_recent_requests.py`: Your primary tool for listing any number of recent requests.
   * `tools/analyze_workload.py`: Breakdown of current active requests by state.
   * `tools/search_team_cfi.py`: Quick view of active requests for the Mark Rob/Michael Sloan team.
   * `examples/fetch_request.py`: Metadata and attachment downloader.

  Is there any other part of the workflow or repo you'd like me to look at?
